briefdescription.para: Create an empty document, that has no name.
Create a document with a name. The name of the document is also the filename of the xml.

detaileddescription.para: Load a file using the current document value. Returns true if successful. Will delete any existing document data before loading.

briefdescription.para: Save a file using the current document value. Returns true if successful.
Load a file using the given filename. Returns true if successful.
Save a file using the given filename. Returns true if successful.

detaileddescription.para: Load a file using the given FILE*. Returns true if successful. Note that this method doesn't stream - the entire object pointed at by the FILE* will be interpreted as an XML file. SeXml doesn't stream in XML from the current file location. Streaming may be added in the future.

briefdescription.para: Save a file using the given FILE*. Returns true if successful.

detaileddescription.para: Parse the given null terminated block of xml data. Passing in an encoding to this method (either SeXml_ENCODING_LEGACY or SeXml_ENCODING_UTF8 will force SeXml to use that encoding, regardless of what SeXml might otherwise try to detect.
Get the root element the only top level element of the document. In well formed XML, there should only be one. SeXml is tolerant of multiple elements at the document level.

If an error occurs, Error will be set to true. Also,
The ErrorId() will contain the integer identifier of the error (not generally useful)
The ErrorDesc() method will return the name of the error. (very useful)
The ErrorRow() and ErrorCol() will return the location of the error (if known)

briefdescription.para: Contains a textual (english) description of the error if one occurs.

detaileddescription.para: Generally, you probably want the error string ( ErrorDesc() ). But if you prefer the ErrorId, this function will fetch it.

Returns the location (if known) of the error. The first column is column 1, and the first row is row 1. A value of 0 means the row and column wasn't applicable (memory errors, for example, have no row/column) or the parser lost the error. (An error in the error reporting, in that case.)

briefdescription.para: The column where the error occured. See ErrorRow()

detaileddescription.para: SetTabSize() allows the error reporting functions (ErrorRow() and ErrorCol()) to report the correct values for row and column. It does not change the output or input in any way.
By calling this method, with a tab size greater than 0, the row and column of each node and attribute is stored when the file is loaded. Very useful for tracking the DOM back in to the source file.
The tab size is required for calculating the location of nodes. If not set, the default of 4 is used. The tabsize is set per document. Setting the tabsize to 0 disables row/column tracking.
Note that row and column tracking is not supported when using operator>>.
If you have handled the error, it can be reset with this call. The error state is automatically cleared if you Parse a new XML block.
Write the document to standard out using formatted printing ("pretty print").

briefdescription.para: Print this Document to a FILE stream.

memberdef.argsstring: (int err, const char *errorLocation, SeXmlParsingData *prevData, SeXmlEncoding encoding)
memberdef.name: SetError

briefdescription.para: Cast to a more defined type. Will return null not of the requested type.
Cast to a more defined type. Will return null not of the requested type.

detaileddescription.para: Walk the XML tree visiting this node and all of its children.
Create an exact duplicate of this node and return it. The memory must be deleted by the caller.
Always the top level node. A document binds together all the XML pieces. It can be saved, loaded, and printed to the screen. The 'value' of a document node is the xml file name.
